sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Can the EU guarantee its own defense and security?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03

sentences.sentence: On specific areas, I would put strategic enabablers for instance, or these strategic capabilities that are very much needed at EU level, such as strategic transport capabilities, satellite capabilities, maritime and air awareness, then at the same time joint logistics.

sentences.sentence: same time joint logistics. But military expenditure by EU member states is significant. It was 240 billion euros in 2022, almost the same as China and more than double Russia. One issue is cohesiveness.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: According to the European Defence Agency, EU states only spend 20% of their procurement budgets on collective defence equipment. How this money is spent is crucial with a dilemma between short and long-term needs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: On short-term needs of course we need to replenish ammunition and capabilities and to urgently buy new capabilities but at the same time we need to also look on the long term which is developing these European capabilities that we hear about in the press and in decisions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03

But there is scope for enhanced interoperability, procurement and delivery of weapons at European level. Some steps have already been taken, like a law to finance EU budget ammunition production called ASAP, or the creation of a rapid deployment capacity of up to 5,000 soldiers for peacekeeping missions across the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03

One suggestion supported by French government is an EU bond to finance military expenditure. Researchers from Kiel University in Germany have discovered a wall in the Baltic Sea that
